awd_titl_txt: GOALI/Collaborative: Engineering Biofilm Dynamics for Cyanotoxins in Biological Water Treatment
awd_abstract_narration:
1605185/1605161
Seo / Mou

Threats to drinking water supplies as a result of increased frequency and duration of harmful algal blooms has been on the rise nationally and globally, for example the Lake Erie cyanobacteria bloom. To protect the public from emerging contaminants like cyanotoxins in drinking water sources, various advanced water treatment processes are considered and adopted by water utilities. This project is exploring a sustainable treatment approach using bacterially active filters to remove harmful algal bloom toxins and other chemicals of emerging concern as the first step in drinking water treatment. However, biological filtration systems for emerging contaminants are not well adopted as they commonly show either low or unmaintained biofilm activities for target pollutants. To enhance the performance of biological filtration systems, bioaugmentation and bio-stimulation were considered, but still regarded as uncontrollable as engineering approaches for consistent results. Accordingly, systematic studies are greatly needed to understand and control biofilm dynamics in biological filtration systems for emerging contaminants. 

The principal research objectives of this study are: 1) to understand the composition, activity and dynamics of biofilm community and their impact on the effectiveness of biological filtration systems in cyanotoxin removal, and, 2) to provide optimum operational parameters and monitoring tools for effective biological filtration systems operations under the pressure of source water contaminated with harmful algal bloom organisms. Research emphasis will be placed on understanding how the bacterial biofilm formation and activity, can be enhanced and maintained by engineered approaches such as bioaugmentation and bio-stimulation in order to improve performances of biological filtration systems for cyanotoxin removal. Specific objectives and hypotheses proposed are: 1) To understand the degradation dynamics (adaptation and evolution) of cyanobacteria toxin degrading bacteria for bioaugmentation or bio-stimulation applications. Hypothesis: The concentration variation of cyanotoxins and the presence of other natural organic matter and nutrients in water will affect the community and function of cyanotoxin degrading bacteria. 2) To investigate surface interactions between bioaugmented bacteria and indigenous biofilm formed on filter media (physical, chemical, and biologically mediated interactions by microbial biofilms). Hypothesis: The formation of biofilm(s) may affect not only hydrodynamics and physical properties (e.g. effective size of media) of biological filtration systems, but also the adhesion and growth of bioaugmented bacteria in biological filtration systems. 3) To determine the impact of filter operational parameters on biofilm formation, growth, and subsequent degradation of cyanotoxins in biological filtration systems. Hypothesis: Optimized operational parameters of biological filtration systems (backwashing frequency and intensity, filtration rate, and bio-stimulation) can be obtained to address various environmental factors. In addition, the proposed project will provide training and education for three graduate students as well as summer research opportunities for undergraduate and high school students. Furthermore, research findings will be introduced in PIs' outreach and service activities, for example, educational programs for under-represented K-12 students and public outreach via Lake Erie Center.

por.por_cntn:
The occurrence of harmful algal blooms (HABs) in freshwater systems has expanded worldwide with growing frequency and severity. HABs can pose a threat to public water supplies, raising concerns over safe drinking water production. To protect the public from emerging contaminants like cyanotoxins in drinking water sources, various advanced water treatment processes are considered and adopted by municipal water utilities. However, these water treatment processes commonly require high energy demand and operational costs with proper waste management. Therefore, finding a sustainable treatment option with low energy input for cyanotoxins is urgent and greatly needed. One sustainable option to treat emerging contaminants of concern like cyanotoxins is the application of biological filtration systems (BFS). Compared to the advanced treatment process alternatives, the BFS do not require major system improvements with high maintenance and operation costs for cyanotoxin removal.

The successful application of BFS heavily relies on microbial biofilm formation on filter media and their sustained ability to remove target compounds in BFS. However, the role of biofilms, their growth, and responses to various seasonal and operational conditions of BFS are not well understood. To address the current knowledge gap, the main goal of study was to understand how biofilm dynamics (formation, activity, community structure, and function) can be engineered in BFS for cyanotoxin removal. Specifically, research emphasis was placed on understanding how the bacterial biofilm formation and activity can be enhanced and maintained for effective cyanotoxin removal through bioaugmentation and biostimulation, as well as optimized operational parameters of BFS. The project team also sought to understand the temporal dynamics of complex bacterial network structures and community assembly mechanisms of biofilms that utilize complex organic matter present in water, combining molecular analyses, ecological models, and network analyses.

With the support of the NSF, the project team conducted both laboratory and field studies to understand dynamics of the physiochemical and community structures of biofilms in full-scale BFS experiencing seasonal and operational changes. The outcomes of the study have advanced our understanding of cyanotoxin biodegradation within natural and engineered systems and also yielded novel insights into the contributions of HABs and algal organic matter to the highly variable composition of bacterial communities associated with BFS, enriching our fundamental knowledge of bioaugmentation and biofilm formation within BFS. Furthermore, the findings provide deeper insights into understanding of the microbial ecology of full-scale BFS by providing a conceptual framework that characterizes bacterial biofilm assembly processes relevant to the performance optimization of BFS in response to HABs.

Beyond increasing our understanding on biofilms in BFS, the findings gleaned from this study could offer valuable guidance to municipal water utilities. Specifically, the obtained findings related to BFS operational parameters provide insights to understand how the physical and community structures of biofilms respond to different natural organic matter in water and operational parameters of BFS, such as filtration rate and filter cleaning processes, which led to optimizing BFS operation with enhanced biofilm activities and functions for cyanotoxin removal. Although the project focuses on engineering biofilm formation in BFS and their role in cyanotoxin removal, the obtained results could also increase our fundamental understanding of the ecology of biofilms, which are ubiquitous in natural and engineered systems.

Research findings were disseminated via ten peer-reviewed journal articles, one conference proceeding paper, and nineteen presentations at conferences and professional meetings. Four graduate students and nine undergraduate students received educational training and benefit. Among graduate students, two Ph.D. students also received internship training by scientists at the US EPA National Risk Management Research Lab. Beyond providing research and training opportunities to research participating students, the findings were shared with both undergraduate and graduate students via the PI’s courses.  The project team also reached out to over 200 K-12 students, including those from underrepresented groups, and introduced them to water treatment processes for contaminant removal via various outreach programs available at the PI’s institute, the University of Toledo.
